description.narrative: The objective of the Project is to increase the competitiveness of Family Agriculture Producer Organizations while providing support for an improved framework of structural competitiveness inducing public services activities in the Borrower's territory.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.1 | Description :The Borrower through SAR, shall cause the Project to be carried out inaccordance with the Project Operational Manual, including the Procurement Plan, the Annual Operating Plan, EMF, IRF, IPF |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.2 | Description :The Borrower shall maintain, until the completion of the execution ofthe Project, a Project Implementation Unit within SAR and with competent staff in adequate numbers with qualifications... |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.3 | Description :The Borrower shall maintain, until the completion of the execution ofthe Project, the Technical Council of Representatives, to convene at least once every semester, and shall submit the min ... |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.4 | Description :The Borrower shall, at least once a year during Project implementationon or about December 1, commencing on the first such date after the Effective Date, prepare & furnish to the Bank the POA |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.5 | Description :The Borrower shall furnish to the Bank no later than 30 days after theEffective Date & thereafter every six months after the Effective Date, the EEP Spending Reports prepared according with OM |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.6 | Description :The Borrower shall furnish to the Bank on or about April 5 and October 5each year starting on any such date after the Effective Date, the Procurement Plan Report confirming that all procureme | Frequency:Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.7 | Description :The Borrower shall: (a) have all the ProjectÃ¢Â€Â™s procurement recordsand documentation (incl. those for the Subprojects) for each fiscal year of the Project audited, in accordance with appropriate |Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I A.8 | Description :The Borrower, through SAR, shall ensure and/or cause to be ensured, thatthe EEPs comply with the eligibility criteria and procedures set forth in the Project Operational Manual. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section I E.1 | Description :Cooperative Agreements with each Participating Entity shall be executedno later than six months after the Effective Date, and for those Participating Entities entering Project implementation | Due Date:24-Jun-2011

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section VI 1 (i) | Description :The Borrower, through SAR, shall: (i) no later than three monthsafter the Effective Date, designate the independent auditors as referred to in Sections II. B.3 of the Loan Agreement; and | DueDate :24-Mar-2011

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section VI 1(ii) | Description :The Borrower, through SAR, shall: (ii) no later than six months afterthe Effective Date, designate the procurement auditors as referred to in Section I. A.7 of the LA | Due Date :24-Jun-2011

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section VI 2 | Description :By June 30, 2013, or such other date as the Bank shall agree upon, theBorrower shall: (i) carry out jointly with the Bank, a mid-term review of the implementation of operations under the Pro | Due Date:30-Jun-2013

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section VI 3 (i) | Description :The Borrower, through SAR, shall: (i) no later than six months afterthe Effective Date, launch a public competitive examination (in form and substance satisfactory to the Bank) to hire rural ext |DueDate :24-Jun-2011

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2 Section VI 3(ii) | Description :The Borrower, through SAR, shall (ii) no later than 12 months afterthe Effective Date adopt and publish a regulation in order to create the BorrowerÃ¢Â€Â™s Institute of Water Management (IGASC) |Due Date :24-Dec-2011

title.narrative: share of state's territory managed under an "ecological corridor" concept ( coexistence of sustainable production and preservation)
100% rehabilitation of rural roads associated with business plans
rural schools carrying out interdisciplinary actions under PEEA (State Environ. Education Policy)
Coordinated implementation of six public programs to improve the rural business environment, as measured by:
share of public financing to family agriculture enterprises channeled through the new rural extension/Technical Assistance strategy
share of state's water resources under decentralized and participatory planning and management.
(iii) Number of farms certified for absence of animal tuberculosis and brucellosis
Project Strategic Plan prepared and implemented at the sector level (Rural, WRM, Environmental levels)
Strategic planning developed and Results-Based Management implemented at the sector level (Rural, WRM, Environment) levels
Increase in total value of annual sales for participating FAPOs
Hectares of forests under Conservation Credits
Studies completed to implement target Ecological Corridors supporting biodiversity-friendly land use mosaics
Farm properties with SIEE (Integrated Economic-Ecological Systems) implemented (SIEE of livestock [meat and milk], grains, forestry, SAF and tourism)
Number of ancillary, climate-resilient production systems improvement and tourism plans executed through subprojects, with project support
Kilometers of rural roads rehabilitated associated with business plans
Number of existing, small agro-businesses made compliant with sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) standards, and new agro-processing and non-agricultural businesses created
Number of tourism plans implemented with project support
Number of self-declaratory water users registered in River Basins
(ii) Number of enterprises legalized, complying with sanitary standards
Number of additional tenured technical staff in the Water Resources Directorate
Number of new regular Technical Assistance and Rural Extension professional staff allocated by EPAGRI in priority project municipalities, by CIDASC to phytosanitary certification and by FATMA to SIEE
New added-value arrangements established (63) or strengthened (75) (i.e. alliances / networks and cooperatives)
(i) Number of Family Agriculture production and processing units registered and certified as complying with phytosanitary requirements
Restructured Sanitary Phytosanitary and Services (SPS), generating the following results in support of FAFs:
Number of Executive Secretariats (“Entidades Delegatarias”) formalized by a legal instrument with the State Government
Agro-livestock SPS Services restructured to include specific support for FAPO
Compliance with Project Operational Manual, including Safeguards and Anti-corruption Policies
New, market-oriented, regional, rural extension strategy implemented
Number of Pilot Digital Inclusion proejcts implemented with internet connection to support enterprises connected to networks
Satisfactory technical, financial and procurement audits
